caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW PROOF IN CIVIL CASES SOME THOUGHTS ON LAND
summary: This legal commentary by Justice Amua-Sekyi of the Ghanaian Supreme Court examines the standard of proof in civil land cases, particularly actions for declaration of title. While civil cases generally require proof on a balance of probabilities, the author argues that Ghanaian courts demand a higher standard—akin to proof beyond reasonable doubt—for title declarations. The plaintiff must rely on the strength of their own case, not the weakness of the defendant's. Key cases like J M Kodilinye v Mbanefo Odu establish this principle. However, three qualifications exist: (1) if land boundaries are unclear, the plaintiff may be non-suited; (2) long, exclusive, and quiet possession creates a prima facie title, shifting the burden to the defendant; and (3) if title is unproven but possession is established, courts may grant a right of occupancy instead of dismissing the claim. The article draws on West African Court of Appeal, Privy Council, and Ghanaian case law to clarify evidentiary standards in land disputes.
verdict: The article concludes that while a higher standard of proof applies to land title declarations, established possession can shift the burden and lead to favorable rulings even with weak traditional evidence.
winningSide: Depends on strength of own case or proof of long possession

rationaleHighlights: In land title declarations, plaintiff must prove case on strength of own evidence, not weakness of opponent's.
Proof beyond reasonable doubt is effectively required in title declarations, though termed differently.
Long, exclusive, quiet possession shifts burden of proof to defendant to disprove title.
Unclear land boundaries may lead to non-suit even with satisfactory title evidence.
Courts may grant possession rights even if full title is unproven.
